description: The National Pro Fastpitch women's softball league announced it's canceling the 2020 season due to COVID-19, but it looks forward to returning in 2021.. That means no softball in Rosemont for the Chicago Bandits in 2020, which was hard to hear for Bandits general manager Toni Calmeyn, though the announcement wasn't a huge surprise.  "It is painful," Calmeyn said.
text:
The National Pro Fastpitch (NPF) women's softball league announced it's
canceling the 2020 season due to COVID-19, but it looks forward to returning
in 2021.

That means no softball in Rosemont for the Chicago Bandits in 2020, which was
hard to hear for Bandits general manager Toni Calmeyn, though the announcement
wasn't a huge surprise.

"It is painful," Calmeyn said. "It's OK, we've been upfront and honest with
our players all along. They've had all the information all along. We've had a
couple of Zoom meetings and said this is the situation and these are the
possibilities. I think them [the team] having the information all along was
really helpful. I think when you don't know and wonder, it gets more stressful
and it's already stressful as is right now."

Calmeyn said keeping an open dialog helped the team a lot, so the news wasn't
coming out of left field. All the players and coaches knew this cancelation
could happen. Nobody wanted it, but they understand the reasoning.

"They know we did everything in our power to have a season," Calmeyn said.
"It's been disappointing, but it's OK. I can tell you my head coach and my
players have been amazing. They are really supportive of the league, Rosemont
and our decision. We had a really great group. No hard fall out."

Rosemont Mayor Brad Stephens knew of the situation all along, according to
Calmeyn. Calmeyn said he was supportive of the village-owned team and the
league through the whole deal.

Now the Bandits have to look forward, though the 2021 schedule is set to be a
tough one as well. The Tokyo Olympics were moved from 2020 to 2021 (July
23-Aug. 8).

Calmeyn said it will be a non-traditional schedule again next year because of
the Olympics.

The league will discuss how it will go about things in 2021 to operate around
the Olympics, which take place during the regular season of the schedule.
Three teams in the league are Olympic teams with Canada, Australia and Mexico
competing.

"To the best of my knowledge, everyone will come back," Calmeyn said of the
2021 teams. "I think if everything is healthy and safe and all that, we'll
[all] be back."

Over the last few months, Canada and Australia dropped out as teams in the
2020 season, but Calmeyn expects them back. They both dropped out because of
COVID-19. NPF also lost Beijing Eagles (China) and USSSA Pride (Florida) at
the end of the 2019 season. The teams that still remained for 2020 were
Chicago, Cleveland Comets (Mexico team) and debuting California Commotion.
Those three teams along with the Aussie Peppers and Canadian Wild are expected
to return in 2021.

Chicago will have to work on its roster over the coming year after signing a
number of players recently to one-year contracts.

In recent months they signed Coley Ries, Ali Aguilar, Janie Reed, Michaela
Schlattman, Amanda Chidester, Hannah Flippen, Andrea Filler and Aleshia
Ocasio.

"We are super fortunate that the players we sign want to be here," Calmeyn
said. "I am not worried about them leaving. Typically before the end of the
season they already start talking to us about when can we sign up for next
year."

One thing that's given some relief to Calmeyn is the sponsors the team has.

"They've all been great," Calmeyn said of the sponsors. "They have all said
let us know when you are back and we will support you next year. That's really
important that they don't go away and just stick with us. I think that they
will [stick around]. As unfortunate as things have been, it's been positive
from the player front, the coaching front and the sponsorship front. It's been
OK."

While the wait will be longer, Calmeyn and the Bandits look forward to a
chance to play again the game they love and help it grow for generations to
come.

title: Chicago Bandits Look Forward to 2021 After 2020 Canceled
html:
The National Pro Fastpitch (NPF) women's softball league announced it's canceling the 2020 season due to COVID-19, but it looks forward to returning in 2021.

That means no softball in Rosemont for the Chicago Bandits in 2020, which was hard to hear for Bandits general manager Toni Calmeyn, though the announcement wasn't a huge surprise.

"It is painful," Calmeyn said. "It's OK, we've been upfront and honest with our players all along. They've had all the information all along. We've had a couple of Zoom meetings and said this is the situation and these are the possibilities. I think them [the team] having the information all along was really helpful. I think when you don't know and wonder, it gets more stressful and it's already stressful as is right now."

Calmeyn said keeping an open dialog helped the team a lot, so the news wasn't coming out of left field. All the players and coaches knew this cancelation could happen. Nobody wanted it, but they understand the reasoning.

"They know we did everything in our power to have a season," Calmeyn said. "It's been disappointing, but it's OK. I can tell you my head coach and my players have been amazing. They are really supportive of the league, Rosemont and our decision. We had a really great group. No hard fall out."

Rosemont Mayor Brad Stephens knew of the situation all along, according to Calmeyn. Calmeyn said he was supportive of the village-owned team and the league through the whole deal.

Now the Bandits have to look forward, though the 2021 schedule is set to be a tough one as well. The Tokyo Olympics were moved from 2020 to 2021 (July 23-Aug. 8).

Calmeyn said it will be a non-traditional schedule again next year because of the Olympics.

The league will discuss how it will go about things in 2021 to operate around the Olympics, which take place during the regular season of the schedule. Three teams in the league are Olympic teams with Canada, Australia and Mexico competing.

"To the best of my knowledge, everyone will come back," Calmeyn said of the 2021 teams. "I think if everything is healthy and safe and all that, we'll [all] be back."

Over the last few months, Canada and Australia dropped out as teams in the 2020 season, but Calmeyn expects them back. They both dropped out because of COVID-19. NPF also lost Beijing Eagles (China) and USSSA Pride (Florida) at the end of the 2019 season. The teams that still remained for 2020 were Chicago, Cleveland Comets (Mexico team) and debuting California Commotion. Those three teams along with the Aussie Peppers and Canadian Wild are expected to return in 2021.

Chicago will have to work on its roster over the coming year after signing a number of players recently to one-year contracts.

In recent months they signed Coley Ries, Ali Aguilar, Janie Reed, Michaela Schlattman, Amanda Chidester, Hannah Flippen, Andrea Filler and Aleshia Ocasio.

"We are super fortunate that the players we sign want to be here," Calmeyn said. "I am not worried about them leaving. Typically before the end of the season they already start talking to us about when can we sign up for next year."

One thing that's given some relief to Calmeyn is the sponsors the team has.

"They've all been great," Calmeyn said of the sponsors. "They have all said let us know when you are back and we will support you next year. That's really important that they don't go away and just stick with us. I think that they will [stick around]. As unfortunate as things have been, it's been positive from the player front, the coaching front and the sponsorship front. It's been OK."

While the wait will be longer, Calmeyn and the Bandits look forward to a chance to play again the game they love and help it grow for generations to come.
